speaker: ANTIOCHUS
text_entry: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.

speaker: ANTIOCHUS
text_entry: Enter PERICLES

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: [To Lords without]  Let none disturb us.--Why should

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: this change of thoughts,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: The sad companion, dull-eyed melancholy,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Be my so used a guest as not an hour,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: In the day's glorious walk, or peaceful night,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: The tomb where grief should sleep, can breed me quiet?

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Here pleasures court mine eyes, and mine eyes shun them,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And danger, which I fear'd, is at Antioch,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Whose aim seems far too short to hit me here:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Yet neither pleasure's art can joy my spirits,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Nor yet the other's distance comfort me.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Then it is thus: the passions of the mind,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: That have their first conception by mis-dread,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Have after-nourishment and life by care;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And what was first but fear what might be done,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Grows elder now and cares it be not done.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And so with me: the great Antiochus,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: 'Gainst whom I am too little to contend,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Since he's so great can make his will his act,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Will think me speaking, though I swear to silence;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Nor boots it me to say I honour him.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: If he suspect I may dishonour him:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And what may make him blush in being known,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: He'll stop the course by which it might be known;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: With hostile forces he'll o'erspread the land,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And with the ostent of war will look so huge,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Amazement shall drive courage from the state;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Our men be vanquish'd ere they do resist,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And subjects punish'd that ne'er thought offence:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which care of them, not pity of myself,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Who am no more but as the tops of trees,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which fence the roots they grow by and defend them,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Makes both my body pine and soul to languish,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And punish that before that he would punish.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Enter HELICANUS, with other Lords

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Joy and all comfort in your sacred breast!

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: And keep your mind, till you return to us,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Peaceful and comfortable!

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Peace, peace, and give experience tongue.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: They do abuse the king that flatter him:

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: For flattery is the bellows blows up sin;

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: The thing which is flatter'd, but a spark,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: To which that blast gives heat and stronger glowing;

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Whereas reproof, obedient and in order,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Fits kings, as they are men, for they may err.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: When Signior Sooth here does proclaim a peace,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: He flatters you, makes war upon your life.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Prince, pardon me, or strike me, if you please;

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: I cannot be much lower than my knees.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: All leave us else; but let your cares o'erlook

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: What shipping and what lading's in our haven,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And then return to us.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Exeunt Lords

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Helicanus, thou

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Hast moved us: what seest thou in our looks?

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: An angry brow, dread lord.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: If there be such a dart in princes' frowns,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: How durst thy tongue move anger to our face?

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: How dare the plants look up to heaven, from whence

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: They have their nourishment?

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Thou know'st I have power

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: To take thy life from thee.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: [Kneeling]

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: I have ground the axe myself;

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Do you but strike the blow.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Rise, prithee, rise.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Sit down: thou art no flatterer:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I thank thee for it; and heaven forbid

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: That kings should let their ears hear their

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: faults hid!

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Fit counsellor and servant for a prince,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Who by thy wisdom makest a prince thy servant,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: What wouldst thou have me do?

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: To bear with patience

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Such griefs as you yourself do lay upon yourself.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Thou speak'st like a physician, Helicanus,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: That minister'st a potion unto me

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: That thou wouldst tremble to receive thyself.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Attend me, then: I went to Antioch,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Where as thou know'st, against the face of death,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I sought the purchase of a glorious beauty.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: From whence an issue I might propagate,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Are arms to princes, and bring joys to subjects.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Her face was to mine eye beyond all wonder;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: The rest--hark in thine ear--as black as incest:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which by my knowledge found, the sinful father

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Seem'd not to strike, but smooth: but thou

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: know'st this,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: 'Tis time to fear when tyrants seem to kiss.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Such fear so grew in me, I hither fled,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Under the covering of a careful night,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Who seem'd my good protector; and, being here,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Bethought me what was past, what might succeed.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I knew him tyrannous; and tyrants' fears

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Decrease not, but grow faster than the years:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And should he doubt it, as no doubt he doth,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: That I should open to the listening air

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: How many worthy princes' bloods were shed,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: To keep his bed of blackness unlaid ope,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: To lop that doubt, he'll fill this land with arms,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And make pretence of wrong that I have done him:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: When all, for mine, if I may call offence,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Must feel war's blow, who spares not innocence:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which love to all, of which thyself art one,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Who now reprovest me for it,--

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Alas, sir!

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Drew sleep out of mine eyes, blood from my cheeks,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Musings into my mind, with thousand doubts

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: How I might stop this tempest ere it came;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And finding little comfort to relieve them,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I thought it princely charity to grieve them.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Well, my lord, since you have given me leave to speak.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Freely will I speak. Antiochus you fear,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: And justly too, I think, you fear the tyrant,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Who either by public war or private treason

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Will take away your life.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Therefore, my lord, go travel for a while,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Till that his rage and anger be forgot,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Or till the Destinies do cut his thread of life.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Your rule direct to any; if to me.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Day serves not light more faithful than I'll be.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I do not doubt thy faith;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: But should he wrong my liberties in my absence?

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: We'll mingle our bloods together in the earth,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: From whence we had our being and our birth.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Tyre, I now look from thee then, and to Tarsus

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Intend my travel, where I'll hear from thee;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And by whose letters I'll dispose myself.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: The care I had and have of subjects' good

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: On thee I lay whose wisdom's strength can bear it.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I'll take thy word for faith, not ask thine oath:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Who shuns not to break one will sure crack both:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: But in our orbs we'll live so round and safe,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: That time of both this truth shall ne'er convince,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Thou show'dst a subject's shine, I a true prince.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Exeunt
